Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the parent needs to prepare for it
Situation2: The meeting is the final discussion before major decisions are locked in.
Story: I stared at the calendar on my phone, the red circle around the home loan repayment date looming closer. My mind raced with numbers—bills, groceries, the kids’ school fees. I needed to keep my job secure, maybe even push for that promotion, to make sure we didn’t fall behind. Just as I was calculating how much I could save this month, a notification popped up: “Final team meeting, 3 PM today.” My heart sank. This meeting would decide the direction of our project, and my input was expected. Missing it could mean being sidelined, or worse, being seen as unreliable. But at the same time, my youngest had a fever, and my partner was stuck at work. I was supposed to pick up medicine and be home early. The pressure from both sides squeezed me—my family counting on me to keep us afloat, my team counting on me to show up and contribute. I felt torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down, unsure which expectation I could afford to let down.
